The jamovi quickstart guide Jonas Rafi sep 20, 2019 Welcome The aim of this guide is to provide short, non-technical tutorials (with pictures!) on how to do common procedures in jamovi. License This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial 4.0 International License.

1 Opening data in jamovi Opening a file To open a file in jamovi, click the menu icon and select Open file -> Browse. Common data formats to use are “comma-separated files” (.csv or .txt). Other supported file formats are JASP files (.jasp), R files (.RData, .RDS), SAS files (.xpt, .sas7bdat), SPSS files (.sav, .zsav, .por) and Stata files (.dta). Got data in Excel and don’t know how to get it into jamovi? Continue reading about comma delimited data below to find out. Comma delimited data A comma delimited file has the filename extension “.csv” and contains unformated text, where cells are separated by a semi-colon (se figure 1 below) or another special character. If you have your data in a spreadsheet program (e.g. Excel), you can create a csv copy of your data by selecting File -> Save as... and choose Comma delimited in the drop-down menu close to the Save as-button. Figure 1: A .csv-file opened in a texteditor.

2 Setting the scale of measurement Before conducting analyses in jamovi, you usually need to set the scale of measurement for each variable included in the analysis. When you load data in jamovi, it is common for the variables to get the lowest (nominal) level. This means that, for example, if you wish to perform a two sample t-test you would need to set both included variables as “continuous”. How to set the scale of measurement for a variable Double click the variable you want to edit. In the data variable pane, set the variable as ID, Nominal, Ordinal or Continous. Lastly, press the up arrow to hide the data variable pane, or the left or right arrows to edit another variable.

3 Descriptive analyses How to perform descriptive analyses and create graphs in jamovi: Select Analyses -> Exploration -> Descriptives. Drag and drop the variables you want descriptive analyses for to Variables. The result is shown in the right panel. Right click the output to save or copy it. To split your descriptive analyses on a categorical variable (e.g. to separate by gender), move that variable to Split by. Click the Statistics tab to see more alternatives. To create a plot based on the above choices, click the Plots tab and tick the box of your desired plot.

4 T-Test: Independent samples How to perform an independent samples t-test in jamovi: You need one grouping variable with two levels (e.g. treatment/control) and one continuous outcome variable. Make sure that the grouping variable is marked with and the continuous variable is marked with (see section 2). A correct setup should look similar to this: Select Analyses -> T-Tests -> Independent Samples T-Test. Drag and drop your outcome variable to Dependent Variables and your grouping variable to Grouping Variable. The result is shown in the right panel

5 T-Test: Paired samples How to perform a paired samples t-test in jamovi: You need two continuous variables. Make sure that both the continuous variables is marked with (see section 2). A correct setup should look similar to this: Select Analyses -> T-Tests -> Paired Samples T-Test. Drag and drop your two outcome variables to Dependent variables. The result is shown in the right panel

6 T-Test: One sample How to perform a one-sample t-test in jamovi: You need one continuous variable and a mean to test against. Make sure that the continuous variable is marked with (see section 2). A correct setup should look similar to this: Select Analyses -> T-Tests -> One Sample T-Test. Drag and drop your dependent variable to Dependent Variables. Locate the section Hypothesis further down, this is where you enter the mean you want to test against. The result is shown in the right panel

7 ANOVA: Oneway How to perform an ANOVA in jamovi: You need one grouping variable one continuous outcome variable. Make sure that the grouping variable is marked with and the continuous variable is marked with (see section 2). A correct setup should look similar to this: Select Analyses -> ANOVA -> ANOVA. Drag and drop your outcome variable to Dependent Variable and your grouping variable to Fixed Factors. The results is shown in the right pane:

8 ANOVA: Factorial How to perform a factorial ANOVA in jamovi: You need two grouping variables and one continuous outcome variable. Make sure that the grouping variables are marked with and the continuous variable is marked with (see section 2). A correct setup should look similar to this: Select Analyses -> ANOVA -> ANOVA. Drag and drop your outcome variable to Dependent Variable and your grouping variables to Fixed Factors. The result is shown in the right pane:

9 ANOVA: Repeated Measures How to perform a repeated measures ANOVA in jamovi: You need one continuous outcome variable for each measurement occasion. Make sure that the variables are marked with (see section 2). A correct setup should look similar to this: Select Analyses -> ANOVA -> Repeated Measures ANOVA. In the box Repeated Measures Factors: write the name of your outcome variable (e.g. My_scale) and name the levels for each measurement occasion (e.g. Pre, Post and 12 month follow-up). The images below shows the box with default values (left) and when the values has been set (right). -> Drag and drop your outcome variables to their respective cells in Repeated Measures Cells. The results are shown in the right pane:

10 ANOVA: Mixed How to perform a mixed ANOVA in jamovi: You need one grouping variable with two levels (e.g. treatment/control) and one continuous outcome variable for each measurement occassion. Make sure that the grouping variable is marked with and the continuous variables are marked with (see section 2). A correct setup should look similar to this: Select Analyses -> ANOVA -> Repeated Measures ANOVA. In the box Repeated Measures Factors: write the name of your outcome variable (e.g. My_scale) and name the levels for each measurement occasion (e.g. Pre, Post and 12 month follow-up). The below images illustrates this. -> Drag and drop your outcome variables to their respective cells in Repeated Measures Cells. Move your grouping variables to Between Subject Factors. The result is shown in the right panel:

11 Linear Regression How to perform a linear regression in jamovi: You need one two continuous outcome variables. Make sure that the continuous variables are marked with (see section 2). A correct setup should look similar to this: Select Analyses -> Regression -> Linear Regression. Drag and drop your outcome variable to Dependent Variable and your predictor to Covariates. The result is shown in the right panel:

12 Logistic Regression How to perform a logistic regression in jamovi: You need one continuous predictor variable and one categorical outcome variable. Make sure that the continuous variable is marked with and the grouping variable is marked with (see section 2). A correct setup should look similar to this: If the outcome variable has two levels (as in the above image): select Analyses -> Regression -> 2 Outcomes. If the outcome variable has three or more levels, select Analyses -> Regression -> N Outcomes. Drag and drop your outcome variable to Dependent Variable and your predictor to Covariates. The result is shown in the right panel:
13 Where to go next To learn more about statistical analyses in jamovi, I highly recommend the free e-book learning statistics with jamovi (2018) by Navarro and Foxcroft as further reading.
